ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of neuroimaging: the physics and applications.

Knowledge: a TON about neuroimaging. I learned so much in this class! The content was certainly great. I was also able to learn about some topics that had interested me, such as cancer imaging techniques, how to use fMRI to track neural processing in musicians, and more.

Skills: Scientific writing, how to write a 350-word synopsis vs. a 10 page paper, and how to give a presentation on a scientific topic.

Insights: Neuroimaging is cool.

I gained in-depth insight into how fMRI, PET, MEG, and H NMR work to analyze brain metabolism and activity. I also developed scientific writing skills and learned how to find papers to research a topic.
I learnt a lot about the imaging techniques being researched on and being applied in the world today.
Learned biochemical mechanisms of brain and relative neurodegeneratie disease
A strong understanding neuroenergetic and signaling processes. I also developed my ability to disseminate and ask questions!
I gained knowledge in understanding the physics basis of neuroimaging
I learned in depth about different neuroimaging techniques and how they can be used to study specific neurological diseases.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course does a great job of improving your writing and presentation skills on top of everything you learn in class.

Strengths: The class is very chill overall, and the professors give really great feedback on the assignments. The workload is also very manageable.

Weaknesses: in a remote setting, it is very easy to doze off during presentations. A more interactive component beyond passive lectures would have engaged us more, I believe.

The nice thing about this class is that it is taught by the students taking the class as they present weekly lectures on a topic related to the fundamentals of Neuroimaging. Which works very well if all the students are passionate about the topic they are presenting on and if they are well prepared. Thw course could be improved by the instructors having  a checklist of items that need to be covered for each lecture to ensure that the rest of the students can learn all the necessary course material in a more consistent manner.
The course relies on the students to teach themselves for about 80% of the lectures.

while I liked that students gave the presentations, there were certain students with much stronger presenting skills than others...and so there were a few weeks in which staying engaged was very challenging because students were not particularly strong or engaging presenters/teachers

This was a great introduction to neuroimaging and the concepts behind it. Lectures were presented by students and everyone was very well prepared as we had to meet with the professors in advance and were able to ask questions and get feedback on presentation material. The textbook was provided online and it was very straightforward and helpful.

Strengths = team presentations, learning from classmates was very engaging and exciting 
Weakness = extreme vagueness in assignments
Content can get repetitive over the semester, and the level of teaching quality (inevitably) varies across students.
Fantastic course! I really enjoyed that all of the students were able to learn from one another through student presentations each week

Strengths of the course include the willingness of the professors to meet with students, provide help with the presentation and papers and discuss materials. Having the opportunity to present and learn from peers is also very beneficial. However, a weakness of the course is also that, aside from the first few weeks, every class is completely a student presentation.
I really enjoyed the presentation format of the course and wished it had been in person.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Although face to face interactions can never be replaced, the zoom style seminars were excellent.
In a remote setting, it is very easy to doze off during presentations. A more interactive component beyond passive lectures would have engaged us more.

The virtual presentation format was okay, not great for COVID but it is difficult to pinpoint a truly better option. The chat was utilized and the lectures tried to be engaging but there was a lot left to be desired in terms of interaction to get the most possible out of the class.
At the end of the semester, shortened the length of the final paper to accommodate for a high-stress environment
Live lectures that are also recorded, such that students have the opportunity to discuss and ask questions in class, but also refer back to the materials.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to others because it gives an excellent overview of the neuroimaging basics and provides opportunities for you to enhance your presentation and writing skills.

BENG 485 presents a good, low-stress way to knock out a writing credit if you haven't already. The class can be boring at times, especially if it is still presented in a remote setting. Also, maybe some degree of interest in neuroimaging would be helpful. But people from various majors take the class, and they all bring in different perspectives on how to apply and approach neuroimaging techniques. So personally, I would recommend the class.

Absolutely, this is a fantastic class regardless of your major. If you have any interest in understanding how fMRI works or how researchers scan the brain, this class is amazing. Many different aspects of imaging are covered and the two major writing assignments are open to any topic as long as its related to the fundamentals covered in class, which makes the class engaging regardless of personal interests.
yes! fascinating content

I think especially if you are doing research with neuroimaging, this is a great way to understand the concepts behind it and also understand the shortcomings of it as well. It is important to know what you are actually seeing in the results from different scans.
If neuroscience major, really useful information necessary for later courses

If you need a WR and are a neuro major, then this is a gentle surface-level introduction to (non-human) neuroimaging methods. If you're premed or are familiar with the content, maybe consider other courses.
Yes! Fantastic course and a great writing credit especially for students more interested in scientific writing as opposed to analytical essays
Yes, I would recommend this course. The content is very interesting and in depth into multiple imaging techniques. The opportunity to present a topic to the class in a small group is also very fun.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live zoom seminar.
N/A
None
Live and recorded
Live weekly student presentations with opportunity to ask questions and discuss.
